It was perfect for that activity with good access to the Tokyo Metro system and hundreds of restaurants within a short walk in many directions. The room was well designed, a moderate size as with many Tokyo hotel rooms but not cramped either especially for one person. The storage space was minimal but sufficient for my basic essentials.  Instead of a flat screen TV, there was a video projector attached to the ceiling. With a little assistance from the technical staff at the hotel, I was able to stream video material from my iPhone and iPad on to the wall, a lightly textured grey paper but not affecting the brightness of the image significantly. Wifi worked well. A good shower with ample hot water. My room overlooked a fairly busy railway line which could be heard distantly during its working hours. If someone requires complete silence, perhaps a request for a room on the other side of the building could be suggested. Although I didn't try the food near the reception area of the hotel, I had a couple of meals in the Italian restaurant on the ground level and these were very good. In the neighbourhood were all manner of culinary treats from Japanese seafood to Spanish, Indian, Cantonese, Vietnamese and other cuisines. I look forward to another stay at this hotel. The room was a comfortable temperature at the end of Autumn. I could wash essential clothes and they would be dry within 24 hours, a very great consideration when travelling light.

A remarkable aspect of The Royal Park Canvas Ginza Corridor is their commitment to sustainability. The concept of providing guests with the option to take only what they need from the reception, thereby minimizing wastage, is both thoughtful and eco-conscious. This approach aligns perfectly with the values of modern travelers who prioritize responsible consumption.

Even the skincare products provided were of surprisingly high quality, a rarity in many hotels. It was evident that the hotel takes pride in providing guests with a comfortable and enjoyable experience down to the smallest details.

The convenience of having laundry facilities available on the premises was a game-changer, allowing me to travel light and still maintain clean clothes effortlessly. The affordability and ease of using the laundry facilities were greatly appreciated.

Positive Reviews: We stayed at this hotel 3 times across our 3 week Japanese holiday (1 x 3 nights, 2 x 1 night), each time in a Moderate King Omiki Room. We found it to be really great for our needs for many reasons.  The rooms were wonderful - well, a bit strange as two were quite a bit more spacious (815 and 915) than the other one (808), but all perfectly adequate, scrupulously clean and well provisioned. Do-it-yourself Check In was easy and efficient. We didn't really use the bar or restaurant - we only redeemed our welcome drinks one time out of the three stays, as it's a bit restrictive as to what you can have and when. We did not find them intrusive in any way, and we also didn't have any issue with the trains nearby (we kinda like the sound of trains anyway). The block out blinds in the rooms are the best we've ever seen... you could literally sleep until midday and think it's 4am.  But the best part of all is the location - Ginza is (from what we can see) the best part of Tokyo for a tourist to stay. The food along the Corridor and elsewhere nearby provides so many amazing and great value options to sample the local cuisine (try Bistro Fukumimi across the road for one!). You can also stroll the wide boulevards at night and marvel at the brand label shops and funky architecture. We just loved Ginza. It's also easy to get to anywhere you want to with all the train stations and lines within a short walking distance (Yurakucho and Shimbashi on the JR line, plus Hibiya, Ginza, on other lines)... so easy if you are transferring to the Shinkansen at Tokyo only 1 stop from Yurakucho. It's also close (say, 20 min walk) to the wonderful Tsukiji Market and Hamariku Gardens. I would very much recommend The Royal Park Canvas Ginza Corridor for your Tokyo base!
